title: Epigenetics and memigenetics
abstract: The field of epigenetics is expanding rapidly, yet there is persistent uncertainty in the definition of the term. The word was coined in the mid-twentieth century as a descriptor of how intrinsic, yet largely unknown, forces act with genes to channel progenitor cells along pathways of differentiation. Near the end of the twentieth century, epigenetics was defined more specifically as the study of changes in gene activity states. In some definitions, only those activity states that are inherited across cell division were considered. Other definitions were broader, also including activity states that are transient, or occurring in non-dividing cells. The greatest point of disagreement in these current definitions, is if the term should concern only inherited activity states. To alleviate this disparity, an alternative term, 'memigenetics', could be used in place of epigenetics to describe inherited chromatin activity states. The advantage of this term is that it is self-defining, and would serve to emphasize the important concept of cell memory. It would also free the term epigenetics to be used in a broader sense in accord with the meaning of the prefix 'epi', that is, as a descriptor of what is 'over' DNA at any point in time.

motivations: There is persistent uncertainty and disagreement in the definition of the term epigenetics, leading to confusion in the field.
The current definitions of epigenetics are either too narrow or too broad, causing inconsistencies in its application.
objectives: To propose an alternative term, 'memigenetics', to describe inherited chromatin activity states and alleviate the disparity in definitions.
To redefine the term epigenetics to be used in a broader sense, in line with the meaning of the prefix 'epi', to describe what is 'over' DNA at any point in time.
methods: Analyzing the current definitions of epigenetics and identifying the points of disagreement.
Proposing a new term, 'memigenetics', to describe inherited chromatin activity states.
results: A clearer and more consistent understanding of the term epigenetics.

motivations: The field of epigenetics suffers from persistent uncertainty and disagreement in its definition, particularly regarding whether it should only concern inherited gene activity states.
Current definitions of epigenetics range from narrow (inherited changes only) to broad (including transient states), creating confusion in the scientific community.
objectives: Propose the term 'memigenetics' to specifically describe inherited chromatin activity states and clarify terminology in the field.
Allow epigenetics to be used in a broader sense that aligns with its etymological meaning of what is 'over' DNA at any point in time.
methods: Analyze the historical evolution and current definitions of epigenetics from mid-twentieth century to present.
Propose a new terminological framework that distinguishes between inherited and non-inherited gene activity states.
results: Introduction of 'memigenetics' as a self-defining term would emphasize the concept of cell memory and reduce definitional ambiguity.
The proposed terminology would enable clearer scientific communication by separating inherited chromatin states from broader epigenetic phenomena.
